unnormalised: I remember when I first encountered the term "bandwidth." Back in the late 90s, dial-up was the norm. My family finally got an internet connection, a blazing fast (at the time) 56kbps modem! We would eagerly wait for pages to load, and my older brother, a budding tech whiz, would constantly complain about the "bandwidth" being too low when he was downloading MP3s from Napster (remember that?).
normalised: I remember when I first encountered the term "bandwidth." Back in the late nineties, dial-up was the norm. My family finally got an internet connection, a blazing fast (at the time) fifty six kilobits per second modem! We would eagerly wait for pages to load, and my older brother, a budding tech whiz, would constantly complain about the "bandwidth" being too low when he was downloading M-P-threes from Napster (remember that?).

unnormalised: He'd explain it as the "size of the pipe" that carries the internet data. A bigger pipe, he said, meant faster downloads. That concept was pretty abstract for a kid used to the landline and Doordarshan. We had to carefully schedule our internet usage, cos using the net meant no phone calls! Mom would get really angry if he was online past 10 PM, eating up all the bandwidth and preventing her from talking to her sister in Delhi.

unnormalised: Then came broadband, oh man, what a game changer! Suddenly, things like streaming videos (which were grainy and low-res back then) became possible. We even started using email more often; my dad used it to send work reports, even though he still preferred faxing important documents. And the constant "www." before every website? That was a badge of honor, showing you were part of this amazing new world.

unnormalised: These days, with 5G and fiber optic internet, the concept of bandwidth seems almost quaint, but it all started with that crackling dial-up modem and my brother’s constant explanations of "kbps" and "Mbps." It's funny how much things have changed since then. Now I routinely download files that are several GB in size, a far cry from those painstakingly slow MP3 downloads.
